entry.title: Creating an Import Data Connection to an On-Premise MS SQL Server
entry.content:
In this blog we‚Äôll discuss complete steps that allows you to import data from an on-premise SQL database to SAP Analytics Cloud .

Here, Our Data source is SQL Database from which the SAP Analytics Cloud is connected using the SAP Analytics Cloud Agent and SAP Cloud Connector.

It is recommended that the Cloud Connector, SAP Analytics Cloud agent are installed together on a dedicated server, and not a personal computer. This helps to ensure that multiple users can use an import data connection without experiencing slowness or downtime.

Below are the steps for Import Data connection for On-premise SQL Database ‚Äì

1. Check the connectivity between SAC agent server and SQL DB on the required port.

telnet <MS SQL SERVER> 1433

2. Installing and Configuring SAP Cloud Connector and JVM on a linux server.

  • To install a cloud connector refer the link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/ae39ab60b1154c179e2baabd26aa249c.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=release

  • Make sure a latest JVM version is installed on the Cloud Connector server.

  • To open the SCC, enter: https://<hostname>:8443 in a browser, where the <hostname> is the hostname of the machine on which the connector is installed, and the port number is the one configured during installation. The default port number is 8443
  • Click on ‚ÄúAdd subaccount‚Äù and enter the details of the SAC subaccount , which you can find on SAP Analytics Cloud. To find the Subaccount details of SAP Analytics Cloud :

You must use a System Owner account to perform the following steps. If you don't know who the system owner is, log on to SAP Analytics Cloud and from the side navigation, choose Security > Users. 

 In the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Account section, enter account ID. In our case SAP Analytics Cloud tenant was hosted on a non-SAP data center, hence our account ID is an email address.

 When the account ID is accepted, account information will be displayed.

Once all the details are entered, your subaccount addition in your Cloud Connector will look like below:

  • Configure System mapping.

Add the internal host name of the Tomcat server where the SAP Analytics Cloud agent is running.

The default Tomcat port is 8080 and the default HTTPS port is 8443.

Enter the virtual host and port so that the internal host name and port are not exposed. 

Agent is reachable.

Add resource.

3. Installing and configuring SAP Analytics Cloud Agent on Linux Server

  • Make sure you have agent installed. To install it you can refer https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/7c35129451f5432194773adac7f89598.html

You can verify the installation by opening the following URL in your browser: http://<Host>:<Port>/C4A_AGENT/deploymentInfo

The version of the SAP Analytics Cloud agent installed is displayed.

  • Also verify if JRE, Tomcat are installed on the Agent server.

  • Log on to SAP Analytics Cloud with an administrator account.
  • From the side navigation, choose System  Administration -->  Data Source Configuration.
  • In the On-Premise Data Sources section, Add a new location.

You can connect to multiple locations that have on-premises data sources. Each location that you add should already have a Cloud Connector installed and configured on it.

You can also leave the Location ID blank to create a Default Location. This Default location will correspond to your subaccount on the SAP Cloud Connector with a blank Location ID.

  • Make sure Enable Agent is set to ON and enter the virtual hostname and Port that you created during Cloud Connector Configuration along with the Agent username password specified in tomcat-users.xml file.

4. Make sure JDBC driver is installed.

  • Install JDBC drivers if not already based on the JVM version.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/connect/jdbc/download-microsoft-jdbc-driver-for-sql-server?view=sql-server-ver17

The jar files can be in any location on your server as long as the properties file includes the correct file locations.

We kept it in SAC agent installed directory and gave permission 777 and ownership as sidadm:sapsys.

  • Create a properties file that specifies the paths to JDBC drivers you want to use and place it in the same file system where the SAP Analytics Cloud agent is installed. The properties file can have any name, such as DriverConfig.properties.

  1. You must restart the SAP Analytics Cloud agent, using the Java option -DSAP_CLOUD_AGENT_PROPERTIES_PATH since the agent is installed on Linux.

Navigate to tomcat/bin.

Run the shutdown.sh script.

Open the catalina.sh file in the tomcat/bin directory and find the line where Java options are set. Modify this line so that the -DSAP_CLOUD_AGENT_PROPERTIES_PATH option is included and points to your .properties file.

 

Run the startup.sh script.

5. Creating the Import Data Connection in SAC.

entry.title: How to Bulk Modify Calendar Event Context Filters Using Scripting
entry.content:
The Calendar in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is a powerful framework for orchestrating planning processes, tasks, and workflows across teams. Each calendar event or process carries context filters ‚Äî such as Date, Version, or Proficenter etc. ‚Äî that define the specific slice of data being worked on by a team or user.

In some cases, administrators or power users may need to update these context filters in bulk, for example when moving from one fiscal year to another.

While this can be done manually using the Calendar List workspace (where multiple events can be selected and edited together), alternatively scripting provides a faster, automated way to achieve the same ‚Äî especially when you need to apply changes dynamically.

This approach is inspired by the SAP Community blog written by @mike688 
Experience Sharing ‚Äì How to Batch Modify the Assignees of Calendar Events Using Scripting in SAC, which demonstrates how to modify event assignees in bulk using the Calendar Integration API.

In this post, we extend the same idea ‚Äî but instead of assignees, we modify dimension context filters for multiple events at once.

Option 1 ‚Äì Editing Multiple Events via the SAC UI

You can update context filters directly using the Calendar List workspace:

Steps:

  1. Navigate to Calendar ‚Üí List workspace.

  2. Select multiple events that you want to modify.

  3. Click Edit Events.

  1. Choose Context, and update filters such as Date, Version, or Category.

This method works well for manual batch updates, especially when the changes are straightforward and performed occasionally.For detailed reference, see SAP‚Äôs documentation: Editing Multiple Calendar Events at Once

Option 2 ‚Äì Automating Context Filter Updates Using Scripting

The Calendar Integration API in SAC allows developers to access and modify multiple calendar tasks and processes programmatically.

You can learn more about this API and its supported operations in the official documentation: SAP Help ‚Äì Calendar Event API Reference

Below is an example that demonstrates how to batch modify Date context filters for all child events of a process. You can also modify the same script to change other dimension context filters also.

Example Scenario

Suppose your planning calendar has multiple child tasks for FY2022.
You now want to update all these tasks to FY2025 automatically.

Step 1:  Accessing the EventID of a Process

To view the event ID of an event, go to the Event Settings dialog and choose Show Details. 

Step 2: Create a story and add the below code to the story widget.

Prerequisite: Add a Calendar Integration Technical Object

Then, paste the following script:

 

// Step 1: Get main process event
//Replace XXXXXXX with Process Event ID.
var root = CalendarIntegration_1.getCalendarEventById("XXXXXXXXXXXXX");

if (root === undefined) {
    Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Warning, "Invalid event ID.");
    Application.hideBusyIndicator();
    return;
}

// Step 2: Check event type
if (root.getType() !== CalendarTaskType.Process) {
    Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Warning, "Only Process type events can be modified.");
    Application.hideBusyIndicator();
    return;
}

// Step 3: Get children
var process = cast(Type.CalendarProcess, root);
var childIds = process.getChildren();

console.log("Child event IDs:");
console.log(childIds);

var targetYear = "2025"; // Enter Target new year for the child event 

// Step 4: Loop through each childs
for (var i = 0; i < childIds.length; i++) {
    var childId = childIds[i];
    console.log("Processing child ID"+childId);

    var ev = CalendarIntegration_1.getCalendarEventById(childId);
    if (ev === undefined) {
        console.log("Skipping invalid child->"+childId);
		       continue;
    }

    // Step 5: Get context filters
    var ctx = ev.getContextFilters();
    console.log("Context filters for child:");
    console.log(ctx);

    // We can‚Äôt assign null ‚Üí use flag and index instead
    var hasDateFilter = false;
    var dateFilterIndex = -1;

    for (var j = 0; j < ctx.length; j++) {
        var f = ctx[j];
        if (f.members && f.members.length > 0 && f.members[0].dimensionId === "Date") {
            hasDateFilter = true;
            dateFilterIndex = j;
            break;
        }
    }

    if (hasDateFilter === false) {
        console.log("No Date filter found for"+childId);
        continue;
    }

    var dateFilter = ctx[dateFilterIndex];
console.log("datefilter");
	console.log(dateFilter);
    // Step 6: Remove old Date filter for the child event
    var removed = ev.removeContextFilter(dateFilter);
    if (removed === true) {

		console.log("Removed old Date filter for -> " + childId);

    } else {
        //console.log("Could not remove Date filter for:", childId);
        continue;
    }

    // Step 7: Build new Date filter dynamically
    var modelId = dateFilter.members[0].modelId;
    var hierarchy = dateFilter.hierarchy;

	var newDateFilter = ArrayUtils.create(Type.CalendarContextFilter); 
			

	newDateFilter = [{
    hierarchy: {
        id: "FYQP",
        description: "FYQP"
    },
    members: [
        {
            dimensionId: "Date",
            id: "[Date].[FYQP].[Date.FISCAL_YEAR].[" + targetYear + "]",
            description: targetYear,
            displayId: targetYear,
            modelId: modelId
        }
    ]
}];

    // Step 8: Add the new Date filter
  ev.addContextFilter(newDateFilter[0]);
  console.log("Added new Date filter (" + targetYear + ") for" + childId);
}

// Step 9: Done
Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Success, "Date context filters updated successfully for all child events!");
Application.hideBusyIndicator();

 

API Methods Used

MethodPurpose
getCalendarEventById()Fetches a specific event using its ID
getChildren()Retrieves all child events under a process
getContextFilters()Returns all context filters for the event
removeContextFilter()Removes an existing context filter
addContextFilter()Adds a new context filter dynamically

Summary

The Calendarevent API in SAP Analytics Cloud provides a rich set of methods that go well beyond modifying context filters.
You can reuse the same structure to perform a variety of automation and maintenance actions across the planning calendar events.

By combining UI-based editing and scripting automation, SAC administrators can achieve both flexibility and efficiency in managing planning calendars.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC): A Beginner's Guide - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction

Let's understand what is SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a unified data platform which means a single environment that harmonizes information from all SAP and non-SAP sources into a trusted semantic layer. BDC can be the organization's single source of truth which provides a consistent, governed layer of data that everyone can use, whether it‚Äôs for analytics, planning, or building AI Applications. 

 

But the bigger topic is why do we even need something like SAP Business Data Cloud?

Why do we need Business Data Cloud? 

Today every organization is talking about being ‚Äòdata-driven.‚Äô We all want to make decisions based on real insights rather than gut feeling.  But in reality, its not that easy. the truth is data is everywhere. But it's rarely in one place or in one consistent format. Businesses have information scattered across multiple systems . Like some in SAP applications like S/4HANA or SuccessFactors, some in non-SAP platforms, spreadsheets, or even external sources like partners and IoT devices. So when companies try to bring that data together for analytics or AI, they face a few very real challenges.

  1.  How do you build a single, complete data foundation that supports modern AI and machine learning models?
  2.  How do you trust your data? how do you ensure quality, consistency, and integrity so that the decisions you make are actually reliable?
  3.  How do you extract real business value from this massive, mixed pool of structured and unstructured data?

SAP recognized that these are the exact pain points stopping companies from truly using data to their advantage. And that‚Äôs what led to the creation of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC).

One of the major innovations behind BDC is how it eliminates data fragmentation. Instead of moving data between systems and losing context along the way, BDC integrates data in real time while preserving its business meaning. For example, if the same business entity, say a customer exists in multiple SAP systems, BDC brings together under a unified definition using the One Domain Model. So business users don't have to worry about where the data came from or how it's structured. They simply work with consistent, harmonized business entities that are ready for analytics, reporting, or Artificial Intelligence (AI). 

The best part is SAP fully manages the entire lifecycle. BDC is delivered as a Software-as-a-Service solution built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).  Because of that all the integration, replication, and governance are handled by SAP. In the past, customers had to manually extract and prepare SAP data before it was usable for analytics. That process was slow, expensive, and error-prone. With BDC, that‚Äôs all automated so organizations can focus their time and resources on building innovative AI models, automating insights, or improving business performance instead of just wrangling data.

Let's take a practical scenario, imagine a large enterprise with data coming from ERP, HR, procurement, and expense systems. Traditionally, every system had its own data units, and teams had to spend weeks just preparing the data before running any kind of analysis. Now, with SAP Business Data Cloud, all of that data whether it‚Äôs from SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, or even non-SAP systems can be harmonized and made available in one place instantly. That gives the business a 360-degree view across operations, employees, customers, and suppliers. The platform supports a wide range of use cases from data warehousing and BI, to AI and machine learning, planning, governance, and even intelligent application development. Basically, it‚Äôs an end-to-end solution that connects data and intelligence across the entire organization. The real value, however, is in the trust and governance that come built-in. Because BDC leverages SAP‚Äôs domain expertise and semantic understanding of business data, it ensures that what you see in your reports and AI models actually reflects reality not inconsistent or duplicate information.

So to sum it up, SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) transforms how organizations manage and use their data. It addresses the three biggest challenges of the data-driven world:

  1.  Building a single, reliable foundation for AI and analytics
  2.  Ensuring data trust and quality
  3.  Unlocking the full value of structured and unstructured data across the enterprise

It's like a bridge that connects all the data sources, both internal and external into one governed, business-ready environment. In other words, it takes us from data chaos to clarity. It helps organizations move beyond just having data, to truly using it to drive growth, innovation, and intelligent decision-making.

Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud

Let's see how BDC is built and how the key components that make it work and how they fit together.

One of the most interesting things about SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is that it doesn't start from scratch. It combines some of SAP's most proven existing technologies with brand new innovations designed for the data and AI era.

Let's understand the existing SAP solutions that form the foundation. 

SAP Datasphere - This is one of the core data integration and modeling layer of BDC.  It is like a brain that organises, connects, and models all the business data. Datasphere allows you to define data models, map relationships, and create semantic layers that business and technical users can both understand. It‚Äôs the part of the platform that ensures data is structured, contextualized, and ready to use for analytics and AI.

SAP Analytics Cloud - This is the analysis and visualization layer. It‚Äôs where users actually interact with data through dashboards, reports, and planning models. SAC is tightly integrated with BDC.  It provides both out-of-the-box analytical stories and flexible tools for ad-hoc analysis. It even supports AI-driven features like predictive insights and chat-based data exploration, helping users move seamlessly from insight to action.

SAP BW or BW/4HANA -  Many customers already have large investments in BW, and SAP recognized that value. So instead of replacing it, BDC integrates it. BW data objects can be technically onboarded into the Business Data Cloud, as data products and reuse them in new AI and analytics scenarios. SAP plans to support BW until 2030, but the idea is to give customers a smooth modernization path toward BW/4HANA and cloud-native analytics.

Now let's understand the new components introduced specifically for SAP Business Data Cloud. 

SAP Databricks - This is one of the biggest innovations. It brings advanced AI and machine learning capabilities directly into the SAP ecosystem. Databricks has long been a leader in large-scale data processing and pro-code data science, and SAP has now embedded a tailored version inside BDC.
This integration allows data scientists to access and extend data products directly. For example, they can take a data product from SAP Business Data Cloud, enrich it with machine learning models in Databricks, and then push the enhanced insights right back into the BDC catalog or vice versa.

SAP Business Data Cloud Foundation Services - This layer manages the data lifecycle from ingestion and harmonization to transformation and enrichment. When data comes from your source systems (for example, SAP S/4HANA Cloud or SAP SuccessFactors) the Foundation Services replicate it into the BDC environment, which runs on SAP HANA Cloud and hyper-scaler infrastructure. From there, it‚Äôs automatically cleansed, harmonized, and turned into something called a data product which a packaged, ready-to-use set of business data.

Conclusion

Now we have covered the Introduction, Why do we need Business Data Cloud, and Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud. I hope you have got a basic understanding about SAP Business Data Cloud. This is the first part of the blog series.

In the upcoming parts, we will cover the architecture of SAP Business Data Cloud, and understand the main components of BDC in detail.

If you have any questions or queries, please post them as comments. I will try to answer the maximum as per my knowledge.

entry.title: TechEd 2025 in Berlin - Recap on planning in SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
It has already been a week since I boarded my train home from Berlin after an exciting TechEd 2025. Coming back from such an event always feels a bit like returning to reality ‚Äî all the nicer to look back on the sessions I had the honor of hosting and the great conversations with customers and partners in the meeting center, at the demo booth, and beyond. 

In case you missed TechEd, don't worry. We have got you covered. 

Virtual Sessions:

Together with @jie_deng  and @matthiaskraemer, I hosted session DA207 - Planning and analytics: Innovations powering SAP Business Data Cloud which is available on-demand on the TechEd virtual website (registration required). We had a full house, lots of interesting questions and loads of live demos (and no demo system let us down üôè). We discussed the overall strategy of SAP Analytics Cloud in the context of SAP Business Data Cloud. On the planning side, we gave an outlook on our priorities for 2026 and highlighted recent innovations in seamless planning and GenAI. We could also showcase great new features like MyMetrics, Horizon theme support and provided a labs preview at how we want to further empower the story designer in SAP Analytics Cloud. 

Besides, I recommend these sessions (again, registration is required):

Session ID & NameSpeakersLink
ST107v | SAP Business Data Cloud: Strategy, architecture, and visionTorsten Ammon
SVP - Head of Business Data Cloud Core 
Prakash Nanduri
Global Head of Product Management BDC&I
Link
DA806v | SAP Business Data Cloud solution road mapTorsten Ammon
SVP - Head of Business Data Cloud Core 
Kristian R√ºmmelin
SAP Business Data Cloud - Head of Product Management Planning & Analytics,		Link
DA203v | SAP Business Data Cloud: The path forward for SAP Business WarehouseDominik Kurz
Product Expert SAP BW/4HANA & SAP BW Bridge
Klaus-Peter Sauer
Product Management SAP Business Data Cloud		 Link
Hands-on

Our hands-on workshop DA267 - Seamless planning for xP&A in SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) was another highlight. Preparing such sessions is a big task but it always is worth the effort. Luckily, I was supported by @jie_deng and @Matthew_Shaw who supported the preparation, the testing, and the session itself. The new live version feature for seamless planning was front and center in the workshop. Participants learned how to:

  • Build a seamless planning model from a view that is part of content shipped with Working Capital Insights Intelligent Application
  • Expose plan data in SAP Datasphere and bring it together with actual data in an analytic model
  • Extend the model with xP&A data and leverage the live version for calculations

The exercise and the tenants are still available! Check it out!

Exercise flow

Thanks to everyone for joining TechEd and for your interest in our content! Looking forward to 2026 already.

entry.title: What's New in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 Analytics - October 2025
entry.content:
As part of our September 2025 release, we are excited to introduce a major innovation in Analytics across SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 and SAP Enterprise Service Management solutions: Intent-Based Navigation. This new capability enhances the way business users move from insight to action by seamlessly connecting embedded analytics with operational user interfaces.

A More Intuitive Path From Story to Action

Intent-Based Navigation allows business users to jump directly from an Embedded SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) story to the corresponding UI instance of a business entity. With a couple of clicks, users can transition from analytical context to the exact object instance they need to review or update‚Äîstreamlining workflows and improving decision-making.

It is important to note that this capability is designed specifically for business users consuming embedded stories. Stories opened through the Design Stories environment for analytics administrators will not have this feature.

For full technical details, you can explore the feature in our online Help documentation here - https://help.sap.com/docs/CX_NG_SALES/ea5ff8b9460a43cb8765a3c07d3421fe/0b8c99cff1604ede87f109026d018344.html#loio476fee7e5d5d434194f3a7f30ddc86d2

A short demo is also available showcasing the experience end-to-end here - https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_f0xp7m42

Key Behavior: Navigation Works on Key Fields

As demonstrated in the demo, navigation is available only for key fields such as ID or Display ID. Because the feature is intended to take users to a specific object instance, non-key fields‚Äîsuch as dates, statuses, and other descriptive attributes‚Äîdo not enable the Jump-To option.

What‚Äôs Coming Next

We are actively working on extending navigation capabilities. Upcoming enhancements will include:

  • Navigating from an Embedded SAC story to another SAC story
  • Jumping from non-key fields to a filtered List UI of the corresponding business entity

These additions will further enrich cross-application navigation and analytical usability in future releases.

entry.title: Slaying the S/4 HANA Dual Maintenance & interim State Monster: Palantir's Trick to Treat Your Budget
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION

Imagine trying to rebuild your entire house, from the foundations up, while still living in it and running your daily life! That's the scale of the challenge many global enterprises are embracing as they transition from SAP ECC to S/4HANA. It's not just a tech upgrade; it's arguably the most significant transformation they'll undertake this decade.

Given the sheer size, the intricate sap integration web of operations with other systems, and all those unique regional needs, no one wants to risk bringing their business to a standstill. That's why most organisations are wisely choosing a thoughtful, multi-year, phased rollout.

Migrating from SAP ECC to S/4HANA is one of the most significant transformations many global enterprises will undertake this decade. Given the scale, complexity, and regional dependencies involved, most organizations opt for a multi-year, phased rollout to minimize business disruption.

While this approach minimizes business disruption, it introduces a costly challenge: dual maintenance the need to maintain, reconcile, and synchronize data and processes across both ECC and S/4 systems during the transition period.

In this post, we‚Äôll explore how Palantir‚Äôs data integration and digital twin capabilities can dramatically reduce those interim costs, streamline operations, and accelerate time-to-value.

The Dual Maintenance Dilemma

During a staggered rollout, some business units run on ECC while others move to S/4HANA. This creates temporary but expensive complexity:

  • Duplicate data maintenance across ECC and S/4 systems (e.g., master data, pricing conditions, bills of material)

  • Parallel reporting landscapes, as analytics must draw from both systems

  • Integration bridges required to maintain end-to-end process continuity (order-to-cash, procure-to-pay, etc.)

  • Reconciliation overhead to ensure financial and operational consistency

These efforts can add millions in IT and business costs annually during the rollout.

What Palantir does differently for Interim State?

Rapid Data Integration: Foundry excels at ingesting and integrating vast amounts of disparate data (structured, unstructured, streaming) from various source systems (legacy databases, cloud applications, IoT devices, spreadsheets, etc.) into a single, coherent data asset. This significantly reduces the need for manual data manipulation or temporary data warehouses.

Dynamic Data Models (Ontology): Instead of static data models, Foundry builds a dynamic "ontology" , a living, interconnected representation of an organisation's real-world entities (e.g., customers, assets, products, events) and their relationships. This provides a unified, real-time "digital twin" of the organisation's operations. This eliminates the "interim state" of fragmented data views and manual reconciliation.

Data Lineage and Governance: Foundry automatically tracks data lineage, providing transparency on where data comes from and how it's transformed. This builds trust in the data and reduces the need for manual validation steps often found in interim processes.

Accelerated Application Development: Users can build operational applications, dashboards, and analytical tools directly on top of this integrated ontology without needing to move data to separate systems. This bypasses the need for bespoke, temporary solutions that often characterise an interim state.

System of Engagement over System of Record": Palantir often acts as a "system of engagement" or "system of analysis" that sits on top of existing "systems of record." It doesn't require organisations to immediately rip and replace their legacy systems. Instead, it integrates data from these systems, allowing them to continue functioning while providing a modern, unified operational layer.

In essence, Palantir Foundry's unique value lies in its ability to rapidly integrate and harmonise data from across an enterprise into a dynamic, operational ontology. This provides a single, coherent source of truth and a platform for building applications, thereby eliminating the need for costly "interim states" and allowing organisations to strategically reduce or retire redundant systems, thus cutting "dual maintenance running costs".

Palantir: A Unified Data and Process Layer

Palantir Foundry offers a powerful solution: instead of forcing every application, report, and integration to connect separately to ECC and S/4HANA, organizations can use Palantir as a single harmonized data layer across both systems.

This creates a ‚Äúdigital twin‚Äù of the enterprise that abstracts away the differences between ECC and S/4, providing unified access to operational and analytical data without redundant maintenance.

How Palantir Helps Reduce Interim Dual Maintenance Costs

1. Unified Data Model for ECC and S/4

Palantir can connect directly to both ECC and S/4HANA systems (via SAP connectors, OData services, or data extracts) and harmonize the key master and transactional data - customers, materials, vendors, G/L accounts into a single, consistent data model.

Example: Instead of maintaining customer hierarchies in both ECC and S/4, Palantir can ingest them from ECC and apply transformation logic that reflects the new S/4 model. Downstream systems (analytics, planning, compliance) can consume the Palantir layer directly, avoiding the need to replicate changes twice.

Impact: Reduces data duplication and manual harmonization efforts by up to 60‚Äì70% during migration.

2. Process Continuity Through Digital Twins

Palantir‚Äôs Operational Data Layer (ODL) enables enterprises to create a digital twin of critical business processes  such as order-to-cash or supply chain flows  across ECC and S/4 boundaries.

Example: Imagine a company where Europe has migrated to S/4 but North America is still on ECC. Orders may flow from ECC customers to S/4 production plants. Instead of building and maintaining multiple custom SAP interfaces, Palantir can serve as the process bridge ‚Äî integrating order, inventory, and delivery data in real-time to ensure seamless visibility and coordination.

Impact: Cuts custom integration and reconciliation costs while ensuring consistent KPIs across regions.

3. Harmonized Analytics Layer

Reporting is one of the biggest pain points during phased migration. Palantir provides a centralized analytics layer where ECC and S/4 data can be combined, transformed, and visualized using the same semantic logic.

Example: Finance teams can view a consolidated P&L across both systems without reconciling chart of accounts manually. Palantir‚Äôs ontology layer standardizes financial attributes (cost centers, profit centers, etc.) across systems, enabling consistent reporting months  or years  before full migration completes.

Impact: Eliminates need for maintaining dual SAP BW or SAC models during rollout.

4. Accelerated Master Data Migration

By connecting to both source (ECC) and target (S/4) systems, Palantir can simulate and validate master data transformations in advance. This reduces rework during each migration wave.

Example: For materials management, Palantir can pre-map ECC material master attributes to S/4‚Äôs simplified data model, identify inconsistencies, and validate against business rules all without touching production systems.

Impact: Reduces downtime and errors during each cutover, saving time and resources.

5. Continuous Value Delivery During Transition

Palantir‚Äôs modular architecture allows business users to build analytics and decision applications that remain valid even after the migration is complete. This protects investments in data products and dashboards, reducing re-implementation costs post-S/4 go-live.

Illustrative Scenario: A Global Manufacturing Company

Context: A global manufacturer is migrating from ECC to S/4HANA over 4 years. Europe goes live first, while APAC and North America remain on ECC.

Challenges:

  • Global financial consolidation required across mixed systems

  • Duplicate master data maintenance in multiple systems

  • Integration pain for global supply chain visibility

Palantir Solution:

  • Build a unified Palantir data model integrating ECC and S/4 data

  • Create operational dashboards for global supply chain using this harmonized data

  • Maintain a single master data governance workflow through Palantir‚Äôs ontology layer

Outcome:

  • 50% reduction in IT maintenance costs during rollout

  • Single version of truth for finance and operations

  • Seamless reporting continuity across systems

In essence, Palantir allows you to ‚Äúrun as one‚Äù even while you‚Äôre still migrating to one.

#SAP #S4HANA, #Palantir, #DigitalTransformation, #CloudTransformation, #DualMaintenance, #SAPMigration, #EnterpriseMigration, #ERPStrategy, #BusinessTransformation #ERPTraansformation

entry.title: Understanding Seamless Planning
entry.content:
Introduction to Seamless Planning  

Seamless Planning is a new integration paradigm between SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere that unifies planning logic with enterprise-grade data storage and governance. It allows SAC to remain the planning experience and calculation engine while Datasphere becomes the authoritative and governed persistence layer for plan data and master data. This means planning teams can reuse planning data across analytics, data transformation pipelines, and operational applications‚Äîwithout duplicating or exporting data outside of SAC. Modelers can build SAC planning models that physically store their transactional data and public dimensions inside Datasphere. They also have control over whether planning artifacts from SAC are exposed in Datasphere for reuse across Spaces or downstream analytic models.

Technical Architecture

  • Model Metadata & Planning Logic: Planning calculations, version management, and data actions remain defined inside SAC.
  • Fact Data & Dimensions Stored in Datasphere: The planning model‚Äôs fact tables and public dimensions are persisted in Datasphere to enable governed reuse and enterprise distribution.
  • Data Exposure from SAC to Datasphere: SAC can expose selected planning objects as read-only Datasphere artifacts, enabling modelers to use these objects in Data Builder or transform them into Analytical Models.

Key Benefits

  • Unified Planning Data: Centralized storage of plan facts and dimensions in Datasphere ensures consistency across systems and workflows.
  • Direct Persistence to Datasphere: Changes made in SAC planning flows are instantly reflected in Datasphere fact tables‚Äîno manual exports required.
  • Optimized SAC Resource Usage: Offloading data storage to Datasphere reduces SAC‚Äôs memory and storage footprint.
  • Enterprise Reusability & Governance: Datasphere‚Äôs modeling and transformation extend to planning data, enabling secure and scalable reuse in the form of analytic models.

This approach eliminates data silos, reduces duplication, and empowers organizations to operationalize planning data across their digital landscape‚Äîwhile preserving SAC‚Äôs rich planning experience at the front end.

Prerequisites for Seamless Planning

Before configuring or deploying planning models from SAC to Datasphere, ensure the following system prerequisites are met.

1. SAC Tenant Must Be Running on SAP HANA Cloud

  • SAC must be provisioned on SAP HANA Cloud infrastructure.
  • To verify: Navigate to System ‚Üí About in SAC and confirm the HANA Cloud version is listed.
  • This ensures compatibility with Datasphere‚Äôs storage and modeling architecture.

 2.  Tenant Co-Location and 1:1 Linkage

  • Both SAC and Datasphere tenants must reside in the same SAP data center region.
  • A 1:1 tenant relationship is required‚Äîeach SAC tenant must be linked to a single Datasphere tenant.
  • This linkage enables SAC to persist planning data directly into Datasphere spaces.
  • This can be done in System √† Administration √† Tenant Links in both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere.

3. Consistent Identity Provider (IdP) Configuration

  • It is strongly recommended that both tenants use the same SAML-based Identity Provider (IdP).
  • This ensures consistent user identity mapping across SAC and Datasphere.

4. System Owner Credentials on Both Tenants

  • The tenant linkage process requires authentication using a system owner account on both SAC and Datasphere.
  • This account must have administrative privileges to authorize cross-tenant integration.

5. User Role Assignment in Datasphere Space

    • SAC users who need to create, edit, or expose planning models must be granted appropriate space-level roles in Datasphere.
    • Without these roles, SAC will not be able to write data or expose model objects to the designated Datasphere space.

If any of the above conditions are not met, then Datasphere will not appear as a selectable data storage location in SAC. The  SAP Knowledge Base Article 3515100 highlights certain errors along with their corresponding workarounds.

Workflow for Seamless Planning

1. Create a New Model in SAC: While creating a new Model in SAC, there is an option available to specify the Data Storage Location as a Space within SAP Datasphere.

2. Configure Dimensions and Measures:  The model created with Datasphere persistence layer is created as a Planning Measure based model by default and the data storage location is Datasphere Space as shown in model details.

3. Expose to Datasphere: There is also an additional option in the Model Details to expose the underlying fact table in the chosen Datasphere space. What gets created in Datasphere: When a SAC planning model is configured to store data in Datasphere:

4. What gets created in Datasphere: When a SAC planning model is configured to store data in Datasphere:

  • A Fact object (read-only) becomes visible in the Datasphere Space.
  • A corresponding physical table (sap.sac.<GUID>) is created to store transactional planning data.
  • Any public dimensions used in the model are created in Datasphere as dimension tables and remain shareable across Space.

5. Execute Planning scenarios in SAC: With the new model now exposed in Datasphere, key planning scenarios can continue to be executed within SAC exactly as before. Seamless Planning does not alter the way SAC planning processes run; it simply extends the option to persist and integrate data through Datasphere while maintaining the familiar SAC planning experience.

  • Create and Execute a Data Action: Develop a Data Action in SAC to update planning data. Once executed, publish the updated data back to Datasphere to ensure synchronization across platforms.
  • Conduct Actual vs Plan Analysis: Utilize SAC's analytical capabilities to compare actual performance against planned figures. This enables variance analysis and supports informed decision-making.
  • Extend Modelling in Datasphere: Build custom calculations directly within SAP Datasphere using the exposed model. Create a dedicated view and Analytical Model on top of these calculations, then visualize the results seamlessly in SAC for enhanced planning insights.

Important Considerations

SAP is actively working to reduce the space dependency in future releases, for latest updates please refer the SAP Roadmap Explorer and the help guide.

  • Cross-Model Planning Constraints: Currently all models involved in cross-model planning operations‚Äîsuch as a data action, cross-model copy step must be in the same Datasphere space.
  • Shared Public Dimensions:  Sharing public dimensions across multiple models is only supported when both the models and the associated public dimensions are deployed within the same SAP Datasphere space. The same requirement applies to currency rate tables, which must reside in the same space to be referenced across models.
  • Hierarchies:  Hierarchies defined in SAP Analytics Cloud are not exposed to SAP Datasphere. If hierarchical structures are required for modeling or reporting, Datasphere modelers must reconstruct these hierarchies natively within Datasphere, ensuring alignment with the underlying data model and semantic layer.

Seamless Planning in BDC

SAP is introducing a unified enterprise planning paradigm through SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). This represents the next stage in the evolution of Seamless Planning, where planning activities are connected, real-time, and driven by trusted operational data‚Äîeliminating the traditional ‚Äúexport, transform, and import‚Äù workflow. Because SAC and Datasphere are core components of BDC, seamless planning is highly relevant in this context and establishes the foundation for deep integration of planning data within the BDC environment. Looking ahead, BDC has the potential to further enrich seamless planning by:

  • Supporting planning-enabled intelligent applications that combine analytics with actionable planning workflows.
  • Extending planning architectures to include platforms such as SAP Databricks.
  • Enabling the consumption of data products directly within planning processes, ensuring governed, reusable, and scalable planning assets.

To understand Seamless Planning in context of Business Data Cloud, please refer to this blog.

entry.title: Link SAC and SAP DSP tenants via Formation to Schedule a SAC Story Based on SAP DSP Live Connection
entry.content:
Create a Formation to Integrate with SAP Analytics Cloud

Prerequisites

  • You are an SAP global account administrator, or you are a system landscape administrator.

  • SAP Analytics Cloud can run on Hana 2.0 or HANA Cloud.

  • Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants must be located in the same data center and deployed in the same landscape. SAP data centers are not in the scope.

  • Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants must use the same identity provider (IdP) and the same subject name identifier.

  • Ensure the relevant SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants or systems in your landscape are available to be integrated in a formation.

  • Context

    A formation is created in SAP BTP cockpit in the System Landscape section of your global account. The formation identifies the systems that can connect with your SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.

    Formations enable the automated integration between a set of your provisioned SAP systems.

    Procedure

    1. In the SAP BTP cockpit System Landscape  Systems page, browse the systems in your customer system landscape.
      Every SAP Analytics Cloud system and SAP Datasphere system you are going to include in this formation must not be apart of another formation. The system landscape features auto-discovered systems in the list.
      • Note

        if a given system is missing on the Systems page, it may be associated with a different customer ID on the SAP BTP global account you're working in. In this case you need to add the system manually, and then register it. For more information, see Adding, Registering, and Deregistering Systems.

    2. Go to System Landscape   Formations. Select Create Formation.
      1. In the General Information step, enter a descriptive formation name.
      2. In the Formation Type drop-down menu, select Integration with SAP Analytics Cloud.
    3. Select Next Step.
    4. In the Include Systems step, select the SAP Datasphere tenant and SAP Analytics Cloud tenant you want to link with.
    5. Select Next Step.
    6. Review your selections and create the formation.

    Results

    The formation appears under your list of formations and a Ready success message is shown.

    Delete a Formation in SAP BTP Cockpit

    Context

    When you delete a formation, the following happens. Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants will be excluded from the formation. Then, the subaccount is unassigned. Finally, the SAP Analytics Cloud formation is removed from the Formations page completely.

    Procedure

    1. In the SAP BTP cockpit go to System Landscape  Formations.
    2. Select the formation of SAP Analytics Cloud that you want to remove.
    3. Select Delete at the top-right of the formation.

    Recreation of Formation

    When formation is recreated the scheduling feature will be enabled again. The functionalities will continue to work as they were before the deletion. For scheduling, UCL formation will only provide enablement of tunneled connections.

    As a next step to create Tunnel connection and perform scheduling of SAC story based on DSP live connectivity please follow the help document. 

    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/18850a0e13944f53aa8a8b7c094ea29e/1c4c615f5d7f4b78a5ae681759a55650.html?version=2025.23

entry.title: Scheduling SAP Analytics Cloud Stories Based on SAP Datasphere Live Connections
entry.content:
Overview

(Available Starting QRC4 2025)

Scheduled publications are an important feature in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), enabling organizations to distribute stories at regular intervals for offline access over email email delivery.

As SAP Datasphere continues to be the strategic data foundation for SAP customers, many organizations rely extensively on live connections between SAC and Datasphere. Starting with SAP Analytics Cloud QRC4 2025, customers can now schedule publications for stories built on SAP Datasphere live connections.

This capability is supported for:

  • SAP Analytics cloud and SAP Datasphere on BDC Tenant
  • Standalone (non-BDC) SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere Tenant

Prerequisites

To schedule a story based on a Datasphere live connection, the story must use an SAP Datasphere Tunnel Connection.

Creating a Datasphere Tunnel Connection

A Tunnel Connection can be created only when SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants are ‚Äúdeep linked.‚Äù Deep linking ensures seamless authentication, metadata access, and cross-system operations.

Deep linking configurations:

  • Option 1 ‚Äî In BDC tenant where SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants are linked via BDC formation (Recommended)
  • Option 2 ‚Äî In SAP Analytics Cloud tenant and SAP Datasphere tenant (Non BDC) are linked via UCL formation.  (Recommended) - Refer to blog Link SAC and SAP DSP tenants via Formation to Schedule a SAC Story Based on SAP DSP Live Connection 
  • Option 3 ‚Äî SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere Tenant are linked for seamless planning as below 

     

Once any one of the above configurations is done, In SAP Analytics Cloud tenant, you can create a SAP Datasphere Tunnel connection using below step

  • From the side navigation, choose Connections  
  • Click Add + Connection
  • Expand Connect to Live Data and select SAP Datasphere.
  • In the dialog, enter a name and description for your connection.
  • From the Connection Type drop-down list, select Tunnel
    • Tunnel connection type is mandatory if you plan to use this Scheduled Publications using the Datasphere Live connection.
    • For tunnel connections, ensure both SAC and Datasphere users use the same Identity Provider (IdP)

Note: In QRC4.2025, you have an option to create new Tunnel connection, however, you will not be able to convert existing SAP Datasphere Direct connection to Tunnel connection. However, if you are on Fast track tenant and SAP Analytics Cloud version 2025.23 or beyond then you can edit Direct connection to Tunnel Connection. If you are on QRC tenant, then this will be available in QRC1.2026

 

Scheduling a Story Based on a Datasphere Live Connection

Once the Tunnel Connection is created and used in the story, it can be scheduled like any other SAC story, with support for email distribution, CSV/Excel/PDF/PowerPoint output, recurrence, dynamic time filters, and personalization.

Conclusion

Starting QRC4 2025, this enhancement supports Scheduling Publication of SAP Analytics Cloud story capabilities for customers using SAP Datasphere with SAP Analytics Cloud.

entry.title: Positioning SAP Business Data cloud on SAP Business Technology Platform : Clearing the Confusion
entry.content:
As we all know, with digital transformation and the move toward cloud mindset, clean core, fit-to-standard, and fit-to-suite, the shift to cloud-based business solutions keeps growing. Many of us remember the term introduced around 2011 when the HANA database was introduced  the SAP Business Intelligence portfolio. Over time, this evolved to BW on HANA, BW/4HANA, and then the ERP transition from ECC to S/4HANA.

From my understanding, this Business Intelligence portfolio or SAP BI Suite has also evolved with the adoption of the cloud platform. Now we hear the term SAP Business Suite, which I think is similar to the earlier BI Suite which acts like an umbrella covering the core enterprise applications. This newer SAP Business Suite connects different areas of the business using SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Data Cloud, all running on top of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

SAP BTP is known as a platform-as-a-service used to design, build, deploy, and manage end-to-end applications in the cloud. It provides the foundation for integrating, extending, and innovating across SAP and non-SAP systems, so business processes remain connected, flexible, and intelligent.

We are also familiar with the fact that we can view all the services available on BTP through the SAP Discovery Center under different capability areas: App Development, Integration, Data & Analytics and Artificial Intelligence.

If you go to the Discovery Center and look under Data & Analytics, you will see SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere listed there. But when you go to the BTP Cockpit and try to create a service for these applications, you won‚Äôt find them.

And that‚Äôs exactly where the confusion started for me. Because they appear under BTP capabilities, the expectation is that we should be able to create them as services.
But we can‚Äôt and this is where SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) comes into the picture.

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud is a SaaS business solution suite built on top of BTP. It uses the underlying BTP data and analytics capabilities like Datasphere and SAC.

To simplify:

  • BDC is not replacing BTP ‚Äî it runs on top of it.
  • BDC is a packaged business solution, not a developer service.
  • You cannot create BDC service on BTP like you create HANA Cloud or Integration Suite.
  • BDC has its own onboarding and tenant provisioning process.

In short, BTP is the platform, and BDC is the ready-to-use data and analytics solution built on that platform.

The next question that popped into my mind, since we cannot create them as services or subscriptions via BTP, how do we access them? We still have a standalone SAC tenant , a standalone Datasphere tenant and we could switch between them easily by linking the tenants. This still works the same.

What changed now is that SAP now sells this as a packaged solution under BDC.
Instead of separate licenses for SAC and Datasphere, BDC combines them into one SaaS package and just one license.

So BTP remains the platform under the hood, while BDC provides the SAAS packaged solution but it is not a BTP service. It has its own onboarding, which I‚Äôll cover in my next blog.

entry.title: Simple understanding of Hierarchies in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics‚Äì Part 1 (Basics)
entry.content:
Accurate CDS hierarchy modeling and understanding is critical for financial reporting and operational analytics. Without well-defined hierarchies, drill-down analysis and aggregated insights become challenging. This blog demystifies hierarchy concepts in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics and shows how they power SAC,Multidimensiona Reports , AFO and Datasphere scenarios.This blog will give you the basic understanding of Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana)

What This Blog Covers

  • Common hierarchy terminologies
  • Types of hierarchies in CDS Views
  • Standard hierarchies in S/4HANA
  • Why custom hierarchies matter


1. Key Terminologies-

Before diving into implementation, let‚Äôs clarify the basics:

  • Root Node : Top-most node in the hierarchy. Has No parent. Signifies the Hierarchy Structure and contains the Hierarchy metadata. A hierarchy can have several root nodes.
  • Hierarchy Node : Represents a group or element in the hierarchy.
  • Parent Node : A node that has child nodes beneath it.
  • Child Node : Belongs to a parent node.
  • Leaf Node : Lowest node in the hierarchy (end point).
  • Hierarchy Directory : Stores hierarchy definitions.
  • Siblings : Nodes sharing the same parent.
  • Hierarchy Level : Indicates depth of a node in the hierarchy. Levels can be defined as 0,1,2,3 . In S/4 EA change level based hierarchies to Parent child hierarchies .
  • Recursive Hierarchy: Nodes can reference themselves (e.g., Org Structure). Implemented using self-association in CDS.
  • Hierarchy Node Texts: These contain the descriptive names or labels associated with the hierarchy nodes, typically derived from the related master data (for example, the name or description of a General Ledger account or Product Hierarchy Description).
  • Orphan nodes, These are the nodes missing a link to a root. You can choose to ignore them, raise an error, or promote them as alternative roots using annotations like ORPHANS = ROOT

2. Example of a Hierarchy-

Company ‚Üí Product Category ‚Üí Product ‚Üí Variant Shoe Model 1

Example:

  • Company (ABC Corp)  ‚Üí Root Node -> The top most node in hierarchy (Defined via Hierarchy Directory and Root node has no parent defined)---- To be discussed in details in another Part 2.
  • Product Category (Footwear)  ‚Üí Child of Company->A Parent Node for Product but this is not the Root node(Since it has Company as a Parent Node).
  • Product (Shoes)  ‚Üí Child of Product Category->Parent Node for Variant
  • Variant (Shoe Model 1)  ‚Üí Leaf Node->Lowest Node in the hierarchy

 In SAP: For Cost Center or Profit Center hierarchy, Controlling Area could be the root node.

3. Types of Hierarchies in CDS Views-

In S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, hierarchies are modeled using CDS annotations. Most common type:

  • Parent-Child Hierarchy üîó Always recursive. Each node references its parent, forming a tree structure. Example: Cost Center hierarchy where each cost center belongs to a higher-level.

 

  • Level-Based Hierarchy üîóNot supported in S4 Hana Embedded analytics as Analytical engine supports only Parent Child Hierarchy for drill downs and aggregations.

CDS Annotation Example:

@Hierarchy.parentChild:
{ recurse:          {   parent: 'ParentNode',   child:  'HierarchyNode'   },
  siblingsOrder:    {   by: 'SequenceNumber',    direction: 'ASC'   },
  directory:        '_Hierarchy' }

4. Standard Hierarchies in S/4HANA-

SAP delivers several predefined hierarchies:

  • Cost Center Hierarchy ‚Äì For controlling and cost reporting
  • Profit Center Hierarchy ‚Äì For profitability analysis
  • GL Account Hierarchy ‚Äì For financial statements
  • Product Hierarchy ‚Äì For material classification
  • EHS Location Hierarchies ‚Äì For Environment, Health & Safety compliance

5. Custom Hierarchies-

Business requirements often demand custom hierarchies:

  • Example: A sales region hierarchy combining geography and product lines.
  • Implemented using CDS Views by developing a relation between Dimension Views and Hierarchy View.

6. Why Hierarchies Matter?

  • Enable drill-down reporting in SAC or Fiori Multidimensional Reports/AFO.
  • Support aggregations at multiple levels
  • Provide flexibility for planning and analytics

7. Technical Details: Where Hierarchies Are Stored-

  • HRRP_NODE_N Table: Stores Parent Node info, hierarchy node level details, and relationships between nodes(Example where GL Account/Profit Center/Cost Center Hierarchy details are stored).
  • HRRP_DIR_N Table: Stores Hierarchy Directory info (name, version, metadata).

üëâWhen you activate or create a hierarchy (standard or custom), these tables are updated.

  • HRRP_NODE_N = Node-level details (Parent-Child relationships)
  • HRRP_DIR_N = Directory-level details (Hierarchy header info)

8. Hierarchy Components & Annotations-

  • A well-defined hierarchy in CDS has multiple views:

Source(Master Data) View: Provides key fields and relationships (Eg GL Account/Cost Center/Product related details).
Hierarchy View: Contains the relationships and parent‚Äìchild links. Eg - Hierarchy(Child) Node, Parent Node, Node levels etc.
Directory View: Provides metadata about hierarchy variants -- Optional.
Text Views for labeling nodes and directory entries . Eg: GL account and it's text/ Cost center and it's text etc.

Proper annotations (@Hierarchy.parentChild, @ObjectModel.dataCategory: #HIERARCHY) control recursion, sibling order, orphan handling, and directory association

Notes:

  • Parent‚ÄìChild Hierarchy: Supported in CDS for analytics; recursive structure.
  • Level-Based Hierarchy: Not supported in CDS for analytical consumption (only parent‚Äìchild works for drill-down).
  • Orphan nodes = Nodes without a parent.
  • A Parent Node can have multiple Hierarchy Nodes/Child nodes but a hierarchy node cannot have multiple parents
  • A node can appear under different parents in different hierarchy versions, not in the same hierarchy( It usually refers to alternate hierarchy versions or variants, not simultaneous parents in the same hierarchy. For example:

Hierarchy Variant/Version 1: Region ‚Üí Country ‚Üí City

Hierarchy Variant/Version 2: Sales Channel ‚Üí Country ‚Üí City.This is managed via Hierarchy Directory.

  • A CDS hierarchy cannot serve as the underlying source for building another CDS hierarchy.

Next Article (Part 2)

  • How to activate Standard hierarchies and develop Custom Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana EA).
  • How to consume hierarchies in SAC

entry.title: Les r√¥les essentiels du consultant SAP : un acteur cl√© de la transformation digitale
entry.content:
1. Comprendre les besoins de l‚Äôentreprise

Le r√¥le premier d‚Äôun consultant SAP est l‚Äôanalyse fonctionnelle.
Il doit comprendre les processus m√©tier de l‚Äôentreprise : achats, approvisionnements, finance, logistique, production‚Ä¶
Ensuite, il traduit ces besoins en solutions SAP.

"C‚Äôest le pont entre les √©quipes m√©tier et la technologie".

2. Configurer et personnaliser le syst√®me SAP

Le consultant param√®tre SAP pour qu‚Äôil refl√®te les processus internes de l‚Äôentreprise.
Cela inclut :

la configuration des param√®tres (ex. : types de documents, r√®gles de prix, sch√©mas logistiques) ;

la personnalisation selon les besoins clients ;

l‚Äôoptimisation des flux existants.

 

" Il ne code pas, mais configure le syst√®me pour qu‚Äôil fonctionne comme l‚Äôentreprise le souhaite."

3. Assurer l‚Äôint√©gration entre modules

SAP est un syst√®me modulaire : MM, SD, FI, CO, PP, etc.
Le consultant doit garantir que les flux circulent correctement entre les modules.

Exemple :
Un flux d‚Äôachat en MM doit automatiquement g√©n√©rer des √©critures comptables en FI.

 "Il assure la coh√©rence globale du syst√®me."

4. Tester la solution (cycles de tests)

Avant la mise en production, le consultant :

pr√©pare les sc√©narios de test,

 

ex√©cute les tests unitaires,

accompagne les utilisateurs dans les tests int√©gr√©s (UAT).
